B000051VWW|5.0|When Sade ended her 8 year abscence from the music scene with &quot;Lovers Rock,&quot; it was as if she never left at all.  The key to her success is consistency and originality, two qualities you'll find on the seductive &quot;Lovers Rock.&quot;  I have to admit that if I reviewed this CD upon release, I probably would have given it 3 stars, as I wasn't really wild about it initially.  But after seeing her live, which inspired me to revisit the disc several times, it grew on me and now it sounds even better.  The first noticeable thing on this disc is the reggae flavor the band delivers, as evidenced on the first single, &quot;By Your Side.&quot;  &quot;Somebody Already Broke My Heart&quot; is an excellent track which finds our heroine warning a lover that she's been bruised in a previous relationship.  &quot;Immigrant&quot; is a tough look at racism, and the single &quot;King of Sorrow,&quot; a lush, jazzed-up soul number, is classic Sade.  I wouldn't want Sade to take another 8 year break before she releases her next album, but &quot;Lovers Rock&quot; is a disc fine enough to satisfy our appetite until she returns again.

It's a book about animal husbandry and the way people connect with animals, even when they have trouble connecting to other people.<br />I've read this book three or four times since that summer so very long ago. 6300213714|5.0|\\"The Warriors\\" is perhaps the definitive cult film -- a flick you always enjoy seeing again. <br />The story is about a Coney Island gang that gets wrongly accused of murder and must make it back home from the Bronx, fighting enemy gangs and police all the way. <br />The 'feel' of the movie is part surreal, part realistic and wholly captivating! <br />... \\"The Warriors\\" is just a great flick full of memorable scenes and lines. I really love the ending where, after being vindicated, the Warriors walk down the Coney Island beach while the DJ offers them a tribute song -- \\"Survival In the City\\" by Walsh/Eagles.<br />I also like the fact that the Warriors is a racially mixed gang -- a group of lost souls in the urban jungle, banded together perhaps for no other reason except for the obvious fact that they're from the same urban cesspool and have a need to belong.<br />I stated that the movie is part realistic, but only in the sense that it never becomes campy; the creators and cast properly take it all quite serious. B00005JKBC|4.0|Despite a few inconsistencies and contrivances, Spy Games is one of the better espionage films to hit the streets in quite some time.  The story is intelligent, the action is brisk and the suspense taut.<br />Tony Scott orchestrates the project well, perhaps overdoing the musical element a bit, but pacing well and creating an effective weave between flashbacks and current day events.  Yet, there are a couple of areas that bothered me.  First, Muir (Robert Redford) was consistently developed throughout the film to be a hardened leader, always looking at the big picture and following the imperative regardless of the human cost.  So, his rogue operation to save Bishop is completely out of character.  Not only is it difficult to believe that the CIA would have been fooled by some of his deceptions, it is hard to swallow the fact that he would have risked everything to pursue a rescue that was antithetical to his training, beliefs and personality.  <br />It is also difficult to understand how Bishop was allowed to stay in the field, given his penchant for disobeying orders and his continual development of emotional attachments to his various human assets.  Such recklessness would never have been tolerated, because it would have endangered him, the assets, and would have potentially compromised whatever mission he was working on.  However, I suppose I need to cut the writers a little slack or otherwise there would have been no story.<br />Robert Redford turns in an excellent performance, giving Muir a very hard edge and cunning mind.  Brad Pitt proves to be an effective action hero.  This is the kind of role in which Pitt shines, playing the dark, rebellious character that lives by his own code and gives in to no one.  Catherine McCormack also delivers a credible performance as the humanitarian aid worker playing both sides of the street to get supplies for the disadvantaged. <br />Action lovers will enjoy this film as will those who like a mentally challenging story.  Irated it 8/10.

B000069HKH|5.0|I gave this album a listen today and read the lyrics, and I was just blown away. While I like rock n roll as much as the next guy, I usually don't find that pop culture has anything truly substantive to say about issues/events of great social significance. It's most often a medium that's comfortable keeping things superficial, happy and cliche. Springsteen, however, redeems rock n roll with this album. Read the lyrics of the &quot;The Rising&quot; and you'll find that the song evokes the events of September 11th artfully, emotionally, and sensitively. Unlike almost anything else, the song (along with the rest of the album) subtly leads the listener to empathize very directly with the victims, their families, and their loss -- perhaps in a way that he or she never has before. It powerfully puts faces to the numbers. With this album, rock n roll has recovered something that it perhaps briefly had in the 60s --pop art's ability to make an important social statement and touch the soul of a nation. I hope you all see in this album what I do.

For newcomers, it is not where to start, but for experienced VU listeners, it is a must have. There are six songs and one is a 17.27 minute epic full of distortion, fast drums, \\"ding-dongs\\", and a really loud organ. The album features songs who's topics include dark comedy, drug use, and sex. The quality of the music and lyrics are undeniable. Each members plays their part to perfection and the overall effect is one that will haunt and make you come back again and again. A suggestion: Play this album at night, when everyone is asleep, and in the dark to feel the full effect. Have fun.

B000005HN6|2.0|Let me start by saying that the musicianship on this disc is excellent.  However, what I received was not at all what I expected.  This album is 85% classical music and 15% metal.  The reviews built this CD up to be a metal masterpiece.  I personally felt that too much attention was paid on attempting an orchestral piece.  To say the least, this approach by Opeth bored me with the whole album.  I love both classical music and metal music, but I think the two styles are mutually exclusive, unlike what Dan Swano and Opeth were envisioning.  I have two later albums by Opeth, and they are a tad bit heavier, but not enough to warrant extreme music classification.  I loved Dan Swano's work, particularly with Edge of Sanity.  That is one reason that his production surprised me on these records.  I also love a little bit of classical influence in death metal (i.e.: intros and song interludes), but Opeth seemed to blast classical to the forefront of every disc they made, concealing metal a bit too much in the background.  I'm not saying this is a horrible CD.  I rated this album low because I don't agree with what audience it was marketed to.  If one is into classical music and doom metal, this CD is for them.  If one is looking for a truly melodic death metal disc like Soilwork, Gardenian, or In Flames; I'd steer clear of this slower, doom metal LP.

B0000026UL|5.0|The 1980s was far from Dylan's greatest decade musically, but he made a strong statement of his continued genius and longevity with Oh Mercy.  Forget cover songs, forget famous guest musicians, forget everything but Dylan's unmatched songwriting ability, perceptive commentary on life, and unique voice.  A confidently mellow Dylan infuses the album as a whole, but, lest anyone think his rocking days are over, he cranks out two stomping tracks in Political World and Everything is Broken.  The social commentary of the artist shines through in the opening track as he laments the dehumanizing effects of materialism, politics, and life in general; these same feelings emerge in Everything is Broken, but they are presented there in the form of a list of problems characterizing and defining the broken state of the world.  I remember hearing this song used as the backdrop of some TV features (probably sports events, if I remember correctly); it was also the last new Dylan single I have heard played on the radio, which is a sad statement to make considering the wealth of great new material he has given us since this album's release.  Inevitably, one's attention is drawn most forcibly to the song Man in the Long Black Coat because it showcases the vintage musical storytelling persona of Bob Dylan.<br />The slower songs also feature some incredible new Dylan music.  Shooting Star is probably the best known of these, since it was included on Dylan's monumental MTV Unplugged album a few years later.  Ring Them Bells is a dirgelike, mournful classic, Most of the Time is a great song about continuing to live one's life after losing someone special, and Where Teardrops Fall is, in my opinion, a beautiful song that shines among the great tracks included here.  I do believe the album weakens as it nears the end, though.  What Good Am I? and What Was It You Wanted? are good but unexceptional songs, and the important theme of Disease of Conceit is easily lost amid the sounds of the album's least enjoyable music track.  However, the greatness that is Shooting Star ensures a satisfying conclusion to one of Dylan's best albums of the last two decades.'s least enjoyable music track.  However, the greatness that is Shooting Star ensures a satisfying conclusion to one of Dylan's best albums of the last two decades.

B000002BBY|4.0|Ah, the album everyone knows, with the songs everyone can sing. Oasis have proved in Definitely Maybe that they're good... here we have them taking their popularity and giving everybody what they want. But it does have faults, which I will get to shortly.<BR>   Hello... what a great opening. &quot;I got a feeling you still owe me, so wipe the s**t from your shoes.&quot; One of those usually-opens-sets songs from the Boys from Burnage here, and it's easily still the most overlooked things on the album. Then Roll With it, pure energy compressed into a decent song. And of course Wonderwall. The song everybody can play on guitar, the song we can all hum or sing... the song we've all heard more than birdsong. I don't mind it. It's a good song... but it's Oasis' most overplayed, overpraised tune.<BR>   Don't Look Back In Anger is the one I prefer over Wonderwall. A soaring chorus, Imagine's opening chords played with more oomf by Bonehead... it's beautiful. But who the Hell is Sally?<BR>   Skipping slightly, Cast No Shadow is one of the deepest, most touching songs Oasis have done. How it sits there so overlooked confounds me. And followed with She's Electric, wonderful singalong fun in Digsy's Dinner vein. I dare say it's better, with it's bouncier, more cheerful tune. Both are favourites of mine, even if the band regard them as folly.<BR>   Morning Glory... Oasis go for all out rock and succeed. Seems like a more powerful Roll With It, though I wouldn't dare say either was better or worse. I love them both. And, of course, perhaps the album's crowning achievement, Champagne Supernova. Liam in rare quiet, reflective mode - and a true lighter-waving chorus. This is the last of the real Oasis anthems... something everybody knows, and you're likely to be humming to yourself for quite some time.<BR>   BUT, the album has drawbacks. Hey Now seems entirely undriven and uninspired, and feels like such a letdown after the powerhouse Don't Look Back In Anger. Some Might Say, Oasis' first number 1... but I can't think why, as the song has very little that's special about it, and is completely blown out of the water by Cast No Shadow. And then, my real problem. The two quiet, muffled bursts of the Swamp Song. Now I LIKE the Swamp Song. I heard it and fell in love with it when I got the Masterplan. But why two muffled clips? Why waste a potential slot that could have housed any decent B-side? Imagine it, the album armed with Round Are Way or Talk Tonight. Ignoring Hey Now, it would have been fantastic. But no, oppertunity wasted, listener confused and eager to know what that guitar/harmonica cross really is. Guess they'll have to get The Masterplan.<BR>   So all in all, this is good... it houses some of Oasis' best moments. But it still could have been more. Some of it is so wasted, so not-quite-brilliant. It just feels like we're cheated.<BR>   Oh well, I give it the benefit of the doubt anyway. After all, it houses Roll With It, Don't Look Back In Anger, Cast No Shadow, She's Electric, Morning Glory and Champagne Supernova. All favourites of me. So for the sake of them, four stars. But still, no patch on Definitely Maybe.
B000002L9J|5.0|This is rightly considered The Smiths best album, and a masterpiece. The Queen Is Dead is one of the greatest angst albums of all-time. Morrissey, now firmly established as one of rock's finest lyricists, had developed on the first two Smiths albums (as well as on a full slate of singles) a unique and fresh lyrical perspective, always delivered in his own, intimitable way. However, by the time of this album, he had truly come into his own, and delivered not only his usual bleak, depressing and perhaps self-pitying lyrics, but also a series of devastating satires on English society - the aristocracy, the monarchy, mores, and religion. Rarely relying on mere typical verses and choruses, Morrissey here developed his own free-form lyrical approach that is forcefully demonstrated in the title track, a blistering satrical piece that is every bit as schating as the title promises - and even includes that rare thing for Morrissey, a bit of self-deprecation. The album includes several other finely wrought and sharply witty stabs at British society: Cemetery Gates (in which Morrissey namedrops Oscar Wilde, a man who obviously had immense influence on him in more ways than one); Bigmouth Strikes Again (another bit of self-deprecation); The Boy With The Thorn In His Side (a song that wasn't Morrissey's first, and wouldn't be his last, to embrace homoeroticism); and Vicar In A Tuto (a devastating satrical look at religion.) For all the album's lyrical strengths, however, The Smiths best work was always a product of Morrissey's self-indulgent lyrics and Johnny Marr's brilliant, vastly underrated musical roadmaps (a brilliant example of the greatness which can spring from working at cross purposes - which is the reason why Morrissey's solo albums aren't as good as his work with The Smiths, although his writing may well be just as good.) These musical backgrounds provide a rich tapestry for Morrissey to croon over. Marr was brilliant at supplying gentle, sing-song melodies to accompany Morrissey's dark lyrics. This juxtaposition is what made The Smiths so unique, and their work so influential. From their masterwork (the title track), with its classic end-song jam, to the brilliant pop songs that they made out of Cemetery Gates and The Boy With The Thorn In His Side, The Smiths have here clearly delivered a musical and lyrical masterpiece. One of the hallmarks of English rock.
B000002C25|2.0|Picture it. Your first album knocked everyone off their feet. Your second album propelled you to superstardom, and before you knew it the country was swaying drunkenly to your music. I suppose anyone would get ahead of themselves. And Oasis, with this third, somewhat regretted album from the Boys from Burnage, did.<BR>   On the plus side, each song isn't bad on it's own. I could easily listen to My Big Mouth on it's tod, or Fade In/Out singled out. But in succession, these laughably overlong wannabe-epics feel ludicrous and out of place. <BR>   The thing about epics is that they should be on their own, after a succession of sweeter, shorter songs. I mean Champagne Supernova sat at the end of ...Morning Glory, proving the perfect, calm yet dizzying end to an almost stupidly popular album. But an album of Champagne Supernovas would just be silly... and here it is.<BR>   When it's good, however, it's very good. D'You Know What I Mean is fantastic... perhaps the album's second only song that probably deserves it's length. It's like a slower, slightly downbeat Morning Glory. The other is All Around the World. Yeah I know, 9 minutes is a joke... but it's uplifting. Like the album, only it rarely lulls and ends with a beautiful coda that I personally prefer to Hey Jude.<BR>   One odd thing is that the singles are good, but the rest feels like filler. Although I consider The Girl In The Dirty Shirt and Fade In/Out excellent, in comparison to the powerful Don't Go Away and cheery Stand By Me, they look like jumped up B-sides. So the album comes to seem like a collection of rather substandard songs stretched to stupid length. And Magic Pie comes as the token-song-I-hate. For ...Morning Glory it was Hey Now. Here it's Magic Pie. Long, dull, no discernable message... it's just Noel rambling, knowing what he's talking about and not caring if we're clueless. Even so, it's Liam's favourite of the album. I guess it just bores me.<BR>   There's still quality here. The title track isgood, and It's Getting' Better (Man!!) is wonderfully fresh after All Around the World. But the album desperately needs to have been more sensible, more contained. Oasis need to remember that although good, and now infamous, they're not Gods. And that no-one short of some infinitely patient monk living in a mountain would have patience to sit through 70 minutes of overblown B-Side-esque material. Easily their weakest album.
B000001GAM|1.0|A legendary recording taken live in 1989. Some things cannot be planned, they just happen by accident or by the grace of some god. If you love Bruckner, or music, or have a heart and a soul, it is incumbent upon you to listen to it.<br />The 1 star is the 6th missing one. (You didn't really think I would give it 1 star, did you?)
B000068QY7|3.0|Over the years, Oasis have darted back and forth like a hyperactive marathon runner. They were great in Definitely Maybe, confident in ...Morning Glory, over-confident and daft in Be Here Now, raw and real in The Masterplan, and tired and confused in Standing on the Shoulder. Any band with less patience would have given up by now. It's probably what drove Bonehead and Guigsy out... the plot, it seemed, was starting to get lost.<BR>   There again, Gem and Andy are there now, writing songs themselves, to make up for the lyrical deficiencies Noel showed in SOTSOG. And Liam's writing too, spreading his wings (no pun intended) with Songbird, Born On A Different Cloud and Better Man. <BR>   The first thing you'll notice is, they don't sound like they used to. Liam's voice seems different, fresher somehow, energetic like it was in the beginning. The Hindu Times gets things off to a great start - an arguably substance-less song, which served the sole purpose of screaming that Oasis were back. And as a warning to everyone else to get out of the way, it worked. It took repeated listens to be anything more than forgettable to me, but now I love it. Especially the chorus. <BR>   Hung In A Bad Place is Gem's first effort for the band. It feels like another warm-up song, not much to it really. And at first I thought it was a sped up Force Of Nature. Still, it has a decent rock-y tune to offer.<BR>   Stop Crying Your Heart Out is the arguable one. I think it's a beautiful, uplifting sort of ballad, like Don't Look Back In Anger. Odd that Liam sang it, but having heard the Noel demo, perhaps he hits the words home a little more. It may be a little dull, but whenever that chorus comes out, hearts melt. <BR>   Then Songbird. I was itching to see if Liam's writing had improved from Little James - and I didn't even mind that. And they have. Songbird is a fantastic little ditty, light and tuneful. Liam can write, and that's that.<BR>   Little By Little is, like Force of Nature, about Meg Matthews - she who Wonderwall was dedicated to. Noel's angry, and complaining and bitching at her like nobody's business. Suppose you can't blame him, but devoting two songs to it? Pity. Force Of Nature I ommited earlier because it's the token song-I-hate. Slow, not particularly powerful. Boring. Little By Little is at least upliftingly bitchy, and it seems it'll end up with single status.<BR>   A Quick Peep is just that. Oasis aren't going to reproduce the Swamp Song, so why try... hence this brief, Andy Bell-penned little ditty. It's different, short enough and sweet. Bit like the album as a whole.<BR>   All In The Mind is more Who Feels Love type weirdness, barely sounds like Oasis, and Liam's voice is at it's oddest on the album. Still, I like it. It's another light little oddity, and it doesn't try to be more. She Is Love is somewhat criticised, but I love it... a jangly, irresistible little number devoted to Noel's newest bird. It's great.<BR>   Born On A Different Cloud, Liam writing in surprisingly mature ways, is perhaps trying to ape Gas Panic. It's quite haunting, quite harrowing, with a nice little \\"laa laa laa\\" bit at the end. I like it, even if it seems a touch out of place on the otherwise upbeat album.<BR>   Better Man is fantastic. A great tune, up there with the Oasis greats. Liam writing sarcasm and promises of self-improvement. Gotta' love it. It feels like Hindu Times with more meaning.<BR>   So. Heathen Chemistry. At times it's a little too new and light, but I guess that's how Oasis will play it from here on in. But the album could do with less All In The Mind curiosity, and a bit more Better Man-like memorable tunes. It's good, I like it. It's a bit of a shock to the system for anyone expecting rock-like tunes or Liam snarling like he did in the good old days. But he's got a new perspective, the band's got new people, the lyrics are getting fresher. The band were changing in SOTSOG, and here's the product. It'll take time to mature, perfectand so on. But what we have here remains classy, sufficiently memorable and, as Noel himself said, \\"More Oasis-like.\\" Don't abandon it so easily, and ignore the critics. If the future of Oasis is anything like Hindu Times, Stop Crying Your Heart Out and Better Man... then they just might be great again.

B000001GXJ|5.0|Bravo! Bravo! Bravo!<BR>This word sums up everything that can be said for this recording. Here we have one of the best (the other in my opinion Santini's with Gobbi) recordings of this neglected Verdi's masterpiece.<BR>It is true that &quot;Simon&quot; is one of the most underrated Verdi operas and there are many reasons. The tenor and soprano parts are not enormous and there are many baritones and basses in the first roles. It is true that this is (as it has been called) an opera for the low voices. But oh boy! What music! When you hear it you absolutely love it. Maybe the plot is too confusing and sometimes it bores the listener but the music compensates at every bit.<BR>In this recording we have in the title role Pierro Cappuccilli, a baritone not quite famous for his acting skills but with a majestic voice. Here he acts too. Maybe due to Abbado's training. He gives shades to his voice and we can hear his anger, pity, compassion, remorse! Just listen to his performance of the last act and you will get the meaning. Many have said (and I agree) that this is his finest performance on disc. (Another great,and maybe surpassing Cappuccilli on some acting aspects, is Tito Gobbi's).<BR>Cappuccilli is accompanied here by many truly great singers. Mirella Freni and Jose Carreras give riveting performances and their voices blend very very well together. Ghiaurov as always is magnificent and his huge bass voice captivates the ear from the beginning (as does Boris Christoff on the Santini set) and the rest (most notably Jose van Dam and Foiani) give very good performances.<BR>Abbado (as in every Verdi recording he conducts) is in his territory. Correct tempi and very nice conducting.<BR>All in all, a wonderful recording of a neglected opera and a must for every Verdi fan!!

0743455967|4.0|I use this book as the first reading assignment in my university composition classes, and my students always react very positively to it although I do forewarn them about some of King's profane language, even though many of them use the same language in private conversations.  Our classroom discussions are lively, humorous, and thought-provoking, for most of my students are amazed that reading and writing can be rewarding.  Most, I am sorry to say, were able to graduate from public schools-in every socioeconomic neighbor-without being required to read more than one or two books during their twelve-year tenure, nor were they usually required to write more than 500 words on any given assignment.  King's book provides these novice readers and writers universal truths about writing, but because the information is coming from a published and popular writer, they absorb and accept those truths: good writing requires reading, reading, and more reading combined with writing, writing, and more writing.  Stephen King's book makes the rest of my semester so much easier, for when I discuss revisions and other steps in the writing process, my students understand and accept the value of each.  Thank you, Stephen King.

It's too bad he was basically shunned out throughout his 14+ years. Some of the lyrics are pretty good too. <br />The bad points:<BR>There's not much creativity to this album. There seems to be a lot of filler to it, hence the 12 songs. There's no particular theme, other than the new change of direction. The songs are overall, too short, they're missing their Metallica essence. Jason only contributes to one song, and this guy has real talent. Kirk's solos are slow and boring compared to what he's capable of. Lars' drumming isn't too exciting. The other half of James' lyrics seem like he wasn't trying too hard. The album isn't really something you'd want to listen to for fun all the time. It's more like you'd put it on for a party or on the radio. The songs lack structure of usual Metallica effort. I think Bob Rock the producer did more harm than good. Now he's temporarily in the band! <br />Overall, it's and OK album to listen to. Despite it's tendancy to get repetative and boring, the good songs are great to bang too. As a metal album, it gets 5 stars, but for a high-standard Metallica album, it gets 3.
B0000029GA|5.0|Simply put, this album is everything that hip-hop should be.  Expertly produced by some of the greatest minds in the game (Pete Rock, DJ Premier, and Large Professor to name a few) and matched up with some of the greatest lyricism rap has ever seen, Illmatic was revolutionary when first released in '92.  You won't find any cheesy, gimmicky skits on this album, nor will you find any superfluous guest stars or filler material.  From start to finish, an amazing experiance.
B000063K2W|5.0|I am writing this review after recently watching a revival of the play on PBS.  Not having seen the movie in many years, I ordered it on DVD afterward.  First, the DVD transfer is flawless.  This film is mostly in black-and-white, save an insert in Technicolor for a fashion show.  The range of gray tones in these old movies can be a revelation to those who have only seen recent B/W films.  The masters of the studios in lighting these movies are long since gone, and apparently their craft went with them.  The DVD has not only the delightful movie trailer that went with \\"Women\\", but also the trailer for the musical remake in 1956, \\"The Opposite Sex\\".  I never liked the musical, but others might.<br />The amazing thing about \\"The Women\\" is that, if one doesn't pay attention to the trailer, it's possible to watch it and never realize that there are no men at all in the picture!  As the trailer says, 135 women and no men.  But of course it's all about men!<br />This is the basic story of Mary, played by Norma Shearer, who discovers her husband is seeing another women.  It follows her through her divorce and reunion with her husband.  Naturally it's not that cut-and-dried.  Her bitchy, back-biting friends go through many of the same travails on a cross-country route to a happy ending.  Sounds boring written here, but the movie definitely isn't.  Every time Ms. Shearer threatens to get too sugary, a few choice cracks by one of the other characters brings things back into line.<br />I really can't remember another movie I've seen with Norma Shearer, so this movie defines her work for me.  She is a very unusual-looking woman, hard to define as pretty, yet definitely with screen presence.  Of course, being Mrs. Thalberg didn't hurt her ability to get this part, and she plays it beautifully. All of the others who support her are equally appropriate, particularly Joan Crawford as the 'other woman'.  This movie was made in one of the low periods in her career, and once again placed her as an A-level actress.  Mary Boland also stands out as the Countess and later Mrs. Buck Winston.  In the recent PBS production on television, Rue McClanahan played this part and the resemblance to Boland was uncanny!<br />Wardrobe for the movie was provided by Adrian at his best.  Standouts for me are the gowns worn by Joan Crawford and Norma Shearer in the final scene of the movie, at the nightclub.  Ms. Shearer's looks almost like something from a sci-fi film!<br />There is no escaping that this movie, and play from which it was derived, were made pre-WW-II.  The extravagance shown in this film was never revived after the War, so this gives an insight into the lives of the wealthy.  In particular, homes post-War were never staffed with the number of servants shown here.<br />Art Deco never looked better in movies than it does in this one.  The beauty salon at the beginning of the movie, and the night club at the end, are creamy and curvaceous like never before, or since.<br />A final note on casting:  Marjorie Main leaps from the screen with her screeching voice and uncouth manners.  Strangely, she was younger than many of the others in the movie, but as usual she was made to appear frumpy and worn-out.  In some ways this appears to be a rehearsal for her part as Ma Kettle in \\"The Egg and I\\".  Look closely, though, and you'll see her youth, here.<br />This is a fairly long movie, well over two hours, but it is so enjoyable that the time isn't noticed.  There truly isn't a 'slow' part to the movie, something or someone is always on the go.<br />Nineteen thirty-nine was an amazing year for movies, seemingly one last pre-War gasp at screen opulence.  \\"The Women\\" on DVD can be a welcome addition to anyone's film library, waiting for the right evening when light comedy combined with beautiful women and sassy dialogue is called for.  It would be a great buy at twice the price.n placed her as an A-level actress.  Mary Boland also stands out as the Countess and later Mrs. Buck Winston. Standouts for me are the gowns worn by Joan Crawford and Norma Shearer in the final scene of the movie, at the nightclub.   Ms. Shearer's looks almost like something from a sci-fi film!  <br />There is no escaping that this movie, and play from which it was derived, were made pre-WW-II.  The extravagance shown in this film was never revived after the War, so this gives an insight into the lives of the wealthy.  In particular, homes post-War were never staffed with the number of servants shown here.  <br />Art Deco never looked better in movies than it does in this one.  The beauty salon at the beginning of the movie, and the night club at the end, are creamy and curvaceous like never before, or since.  <br />A final note on casting:  Marjorie Main leaps from the screen with her screeching voice and uncouth manners. It would be a great buy at twice the price.

B000069HKH|4.0|from Bruce at this stage of his career. If you want to hear memorable contributions from Clarence Clemons and other members of the band you will again be disappointed.  If you want to hear a pretty decent album and take bruce for what he is at this stage of his career (after over 30 years of giving it everything he had), then you will enjoy this cd. Although there are really no bad songs on this cd (remarkable for a 15 track cd), there aren't any that will blow you away either. The most compelling songs are \\"Lonesome Day\\"(nice violin touch with a powerful chord structure), \\"Into The Fire\\"(you can feel it in your heart), \\"Empty Sky\\"(Bruce conveys the isolation perfectly), \\"Worlds Apart\\"(the most creative and powerful song on the cd), \\"Let's Be Friends\\"(borderline corn but Bruce pulls it off), \\"Your Missing\\"(very moving), and \\"The Rising\\"(traditional Springsteen). The worst song is \\"Countin' On A Miracle\\"(forgettable) and \\"My City Of Ruins\\" is much better than the deplorable version from the \\"Tribute\\" cd. I gave this cd 4 and a half stars not because it was a really great cd but because it was an honest effort from Springsteen to produce quality, meaningful music rather than hacking something out and selling it on his name and I appreciate that. So if you're a Springsteen fan you should buy this cd with the appropriate expectations. If you're not a Springsteen fan already this cd probably won't turn you into one. ...

B00004Y6O9|5.0|A landmark recording for rock music as a whole, and a cd that every self-respecting fan of the genre should own.<br />Eddie Van Halen's guitar technique was utterly revolutionary and set the tone for the entire 1980's guitar virtuoso movement as well as influencing most every guitarist since, but when complemented by David Lee Roth's masterful showmanship, Michael Anthony's spleen rumbling bass and Alex Van Halen's powerful drums the sheer quality of musicianship resulted in a sure fire classic. Also, a relatively lengthy gestation period resulted in the band creating one of the most polished, consistent debut albums ever.<br />This is an essentially a flawless recording, from the ryhthmic stomp and melodic chorus of 'Runnin' with the devil' through to the Pseudo-thrash, punk influenced histrionics of 'On Fire'.  Sandwiched between these two songs, rock standards in themselves, are such timeless classics as the guitar masterpiece 'Eruption', the blueprint for almost every guitar solo for the next 20 years, the stunning Kinks cover 'You Really got me' or the slightly darker, rollercoater ride that is 'Ain't talkin' bout love' (both of which garnered huge media attention). All are an exhibition of the albums quality.<br />Even the less publicised tracks, such as the jaw droppingly well executed 'Im the One', the riotous 'Atomic Punk', the melodic 'Little Dreamer' or the blues standard 'Ice Cream man' which is reworked in inimitable Halen fashion are incredible.<br />In short, buy this album. The musicianship is achingly good, the consistency over every single track sustained masterfully, the lyrics by turns beautifully ironic or wonderfully uplifting. Add to this the fact that it is possibly the only album in the world that has made me laugh out loud with joy after listening to it through and my enthusiasm becomes apparent.<br />I honestly cannot recommend this record enough.

B000068QY7|5.0|Okay, I'll break down with my input.  I've been a long time Oasis fan.  From their first album all the way through this gem.  Every Oasis album or demo or live performance or boot I've ever heard has its ups and downs.  All of Oasis' previously released &quot;official&quot; CD's have had their ups and downs also.  But overall, I can say this is close to their best.  And though it's short, hey, remember the times the great supergroups of yore used to put out a new &quot;short&quot; piece of vinyl every year or 6 months?  I hope this is a renewal of sorts for Oasis and that we will see a new CD in the not too far distant future.<br />If you have ever gotten into Oasis (and it's a learning and growing process) at all, you will find some of their best work on this CD, &quot;Heathen Chemistry.&quot;  A few tracks rival previous classics like &quot;Wonderwall,&quot; &quot;Champagne Supernova,&quot; and though there is no long epic here (boo...), a listen to this on repeat mode is necessary to break all resistance.  Which is futile.  Because with this CD, there are some instant classics.  And though there are faults, they are minor.  There is no bad song on this album really, but then I don't think I've ever heard a &quot;bad&quot; Oasis song.  Just some ya like a lot better than others.<br />The best tracks IMO are, in no order, The Hindu Times, Stop Crying Your Heart Out, (Probably) All in the Mind, and Born on a Different Cloud.  These are all Oasis at their best.  Force of Nature, Hung in a Bad Place, Little by Little and Better Man are very good.  Hey, that's most of the album folks.  Buy it!  Share it.  Those rumors of Oasis' demise have been greatly exaggerated.<br />The opening track The Hindu Times has a defiant, positive drive to it, with a guitar riff that is impossible to dislike.  In Stop Crying Your Heart Out, within a sad and reflective context, there is a positive slow beat to this.  It's a beautiful song.  (Probably) All in the Mind features great backup vocals and an extended guitar solo (again, not nearly long enough), with old time fuzz.  Great stuff.  The guitar work throughout is brilliant and simple and complex at the same time.<br />If there was a &quot;best&quot; song here, I'd go with &quot;Born on a Different Cloud&quot; which uses a very simple chord progression to deliver a powerful &quot;best of the Beatles&quot; sound.  Complete with psychedelic opening, to the eerie (whether intentional or otherwise doesn't matter to me, it's a tribute at the very least), JOHN LENNON influence.  Well, it's a great song over all, and complete with handclaps, guitar work great as always, synthesized sounds and embellishments, and a short solo which sounds exactly like George Harrison.  If this had to be Oasis' last song ever on some future tribute album, great.<br />In summary, this ranks alongside all of the rest of their work, all of which I've found consistently great, innovative, easy to listen to on repeat mode, and my quibbles are few.  I do wish the CD was a lot longer, especially the great instrumental on the album, &quot;A Quick Peep,&quot; which is OH, WAY TOO QUICK at only a bit over a minute.  I could've listened to this little &quot;jam&quot; for 10 minutes or more.  Perhaps in the future, they will do such a version &quot;A Long Peep.&quot;  In many ways, &quot;A Quick Peep&quot; may signal a different direction for Oasis in the future, one more towards a progressive nature, which I think would be fantastic.  A Quick Peep sounds very much like an old Genesis song in their prime.  Just wish it were a lot longer.<br />Not maybe, definetly GET IT...ocals and an extended guitar solo (again, not nearly long enough), with old time fuzz.  Great stuff. B000002HEP|5.0|This is an album that defines a genre, and with such a distinction one would expect nothing short of a masterwork. Astoundingly, Kyuss deliver an album here that wildly exceeds anyones expectations.<br />Kyuss are far, far more than the Black Sabbath clones that they are occasionally labelled as by some narrow minded, ignorant music fans (and critics alike).<br />Describing their sound in mere words is almost impossible. Imagine guitars that are so heavy that thay appear to be an aural wall of noise, yet often screech unexpectedly into tripped out interludes. Imagine bass so low that it is almost inaudible yet utterly essential to the overall effect (and is delivered on this release by one of the best in the business-Scott Reeder). Imagine drums often imitated yet never bettered, played in masterful style. Imagine vocals so raw and heart rending they seem supernatural, grating even, yet compelling and likeable, delivered in the inimitable style of John Garcia.<br />This is Kyuss.<br />As for the album itself: from the churning stomp of the super heavy 'Gardenia' to the melodic, catchy acoustics of 'Whitewater' it is flawless.<br />'Asteroid' is a wonderfull instrumental, searing like the desert sun in which Kyuss' members spent their youth.<br />Supa scoopy and Mighty scoop (ridiculous title admittedly) is a speedy, martial 4 minutes with a bizzare stop/start ending effectively drawing it to a mighty conclusion.<br />100 degress is a lightning fast wall of noise, while the 10 minutes+ of the lighter, acoustic 'Space Cadet' and 'Demon Cleaner' is some of the most compelling, emotive music ever created, as well as introducing some welcome diversity to the release and showcasing the bands ample musical talents.<br />Finally, 'Odyessy', 'Conan Troutman' and 'N.O' drag the album to a cataclysmic conclusion, before the mellower 'Whitewater' allows us scant time to reflect upon the genius just witnessed.<br />Even if you are not a huge stoner rock fan (im not), or even a huge metal fan, this album is well worth the purchase.<br />Hugely recommended.s album is well worth the purchase.<BR>Hugely recommended.

B000066F6H|5.0|The Hives burst upon the scene like a breath of fresh country air after one has been confined to the smog-filled urban air for way too long. I don't how often you all listen to modern rock radio, in all of its way overblown post-grunge/punk-pop sound, but I know I listen often, and I feel that the Hives definetely are the rush of oxygen that the current popular music scene needs.<BR>The album itself is a punk masterpiece, taking the genre back to its roots, seemingly ripping, clawing, and practically tearing the tree itself out the ground. The best tracks are (in no particular order): Die, Alright!, Supply and Demand, Hate to Say I Told You So(widely played single), and A Get Together to Tear It Apart. Still, this is not to say that the other tracks are not great; they are, the previous are just my favorites. This band is certainly more punk than anything else current out there; and,no, being punk really has nothing to do at all with the way you dress, having piercings, or only being able to play three chords in eighth note patterns, but,rather, it is purely attitude. And the Hives have it. And I hope you soon will, too.
B00004XONN|5.0|I am familiar with all albums previous to &quot;Kid A&quot; that Radiohead has put out, and I have to say this is, by far, such a mark of growth and breadth of influence it's hard to write a review in 1000 words or less.  It's the biggest piece of musical genius to hit the music world this decade.  Radiohead is often overlooked for their genius, I believe, because it's not the modern, pop-y, song-of-the-minute music we're used to these days.  Instead, Radiohead crafts music with thought, not only to lyrics (or lack thereof, as the case may be), but song structure and texture as well; this is evidenced perfectly in &quot;How To Disapear Completely&quot;, possibly the most complex and sonically textured song Radiohead has written to date.  It hums, ebbs, flows, then warps into other soundscapes and comes back to perfect harmony again.  Genius.  They are truly musicians, even modern day composers, if you will.  On &quot;Kid A&quot; they not only delve deeper into themselves with self-criticism but also reflect on society today, as is evidenced in &quot;Everything In Its Right Place&quot;.  This album as a whole flows better than any other to date.  Those people who put this album down aren't unintelligent, they just don't understand well-crafted, thought-provoking music when they hear it.  Pity on them.

B00000I8UF|5.0|AND I LIKE THIS ALBUM A LOT!!!! Moanin' has got to be one of the most enjoyable albums I've ever heard, in jazz or any other genre for that matter. The tracks: memorable. The playing: extraordinary. The vibe: infectious! Art Blakey and The Jazz Messengers manage to knock one out of the ballpark on this Blue Note date and the remastering job done by original recording engineer Rudy Van Gelder is all the more reason to pick this one up for your collection. The title track is truly classic (just listen to the inventive solos by trumpeter Lee Morgan and pianist Bobby Timmons on the original version if you don't believe me!) Along Came Betty just swings like nobody's business and the Drum Thunder Suite might as well be the highlight of the entire album, showcasing the explosive, polyrhythmic style that has since become Blakey's calling card (check out the work he pulls off with the mallets, MINDBLOWING STUFF!).<br />As I've stated before, I don't claim to know all there is to know in the world of jazz, but I took a chance on Moanin' based on several recommendations and found it to be a legitimate keeper. Hell, you don't even have to like jazz to get into this album. GOOD MUSIC IS GOOD MUSIC, PERIOD!

Marred somewhat by excessive and pointless swearing (...) this is nonetheless an intelligent effort that imroves decidedly on repeated viewing.

B00005Q3TZ|5.0|A movie similar to \\"The Patriot\\" in that it takes an American War and sets against it a touching personal story, while doing its best to sanitize black spots in our history and smooth out history to make it a better plot device, at the expense of depth.  Racism is presented as merely an afterthought, and there's Cuba Gooding, Jr. playing a black Navy cook for one of two times.<br />The movie appears historically accurate to the extent that it focuses on the attack.  Minor events can and should be made fictitious so as not to focus on specific individuals the way a documentary would.  The story you see in the movie is one which could have happenend; fragments of it almost certainly happened, like the underage runaway who lies about her age to get into the Navy.  The cause of the love triangle looks like it came out of a modern soap opera, but that can be forgiven.<br />The movie has three distinct parts: before, during, and post-attack, and could almost have been broken up into three separate movies (the movie runs LONG, almost four hours).  The attack sequence is a bit unnerving for Americans who aren't used to seeing us get slaughtered, but The Patriot already covered that ground successfully.  As in The Patriot, the Japanese perspective is given a voice, including one brief scene of a young Japanese soldier writting a love letter in which he speaks of the willingness to die for his country.<br />For those who put down the writing of the film, it did make effective use of foreshadowing twice, once where Rafe and Danny play \\"chicken\\" in the air, with Rafe defending the \\"stunt\\" as a way of \\"keeping his edge\\" (later on in the film they use this stunt in combat), and in another, where the Cuba Gooding character complaints to Evelyn about not being allowed to fire weapons yet.  \\"Let's hope you never have to\\" is her eerie response.<br />While D-Day may have been the beginning of the end of World War II, the war's turning point could be traced to the point at which the remains of the Pacific Fleet, in the midst of being attacked by an airborne fleet numbering almost four hundred, began to fight back from the ground, and in the air, taking out 29 enemy aircraft.  At that point, the third wave of the attack was called off because the element of surprise, Japan's major weapon, was gone.<br />For anyone who wonders why we dropped atomic weapons on Japan, Pearl Harbor answers them.  This was a brutal enemy of tremendous intelligence and force, using weapons specifically designed to destroy us and which were superior to our own.<br />On the social side, the film provides a bit of a time capsule of the racism and sexism inherent in the era: blacks are shown playing music, boxing, and performing menial tasks in uniform, while women are shown in the nurturing roles of nurses, wielding influence over the men on a personal level while leaving them in charge institutionally.  The image portrayed in both cases is not one of oppression, but of a system in which gender and racial roles were well-defined and people were expected to conform to those roles.  The women of that era sought power not by advancing in rank, but instead by showing the vulnerability of the males of that era either on the examining table to receive an injection, or in a social setting where the men solicit the women's attention.  Once the attack commences, the women wind up in charge because most of them were away from its location and then rushed to the scene, suffering casualties of their own.  Some uneasy questions about whether we were better off then or now with the way things are or were are raised, and the answers are not simple.<br />Once the shock of the attack wore off, and the soldiers began to regroup, the transformation from the military \\"working holiday\\" that many thought their stations were to an armed force united against a common and deadly enemy was complete.  This movie captured brilliantly both the ferocity and impotence of the attack: a seemingly never-ending assault on our ships is juxtaposed against a cowardly invader retreating the moment we began to fight back.<br />The casting of Dan Ackroyd as a decoder was an excellent detail; no other actor in Hollywood would have done with those few lines he had what he was able to.  ... .<br />Like other recent epics such as \\"The Patriot\\" or \\"Any Given Sunday,\\" taking a large slice of Americana and putting it on film to perfection is a hopelessly lost cause. Those who would make the film historically accurate would offer a dull rendition of it, too focused on details and not cognizant of the need to be able to tell a story and make it interesting as a movie, without compromising the facts upon which it is based.<br />This movie achieves these aims on all counts.  A compelling production.nding assault on our ships is juxtaposed against a cowardly invader retreating the moment we began to fight back.  <br />The casting of Dan Ackroyd as a decoder was an excellent detail; no other actor in Hollywood would have done with those few lines he had what he was able to.  ... .<br />Like other recent epics such as \\"The Patriot\\" or \\"Any Given Sunday,\\" taking a large slice of Americana and putting it on film to perfection is a hopelessly lost cause. Those who would make the film historically accurate would offer a dull rendition of it, too focused on details and not cognizant of the need to be able to tell a story and make it interesting as a movie, without compromising the facts upon which it is based.<br />This movie achieves these aims on all counts.  A compelling production.

B00005JKLZ|2.0|Yet another example of what happens when an otherwise philosophical story falls victim to Hollywood's thirst for the young target-market.  While the time travel sequences are beauties to behold in their own right, one quickly discovers that there is little else besides them to enjoy in the movie.  The story is flat, and deviates from the author's original story and intent even more so than the 1960 version.<br />The Eloi are not the mentally-underdeveloped, short, childlike beings with large eyes and small mouths, but rather are tanned, voluptuous creatures with intelligence enough to quip at the Time Traveler as being a `wandering idiot'; the Morlocks are not the pale, collective workers operating on the base instinct of habit and hunger, but rather are overwhelming monsters resembling more the undead than an offshoot of humanity, led of course by a charismatic ultra-intelligent Uber-Morlock (who somehow has the clairvoyance to dictate to the Time Traveler why he is there and why his cause will fail).<br />This movie, as the first, deviates from the original novel: Weena (Mara), instead of her dramatic death in a massive fire trying to escape the Morlocks, lives to serve as romantic appeal as mate of the Time Traveler.  And once again we miss the awe-inspiring scene where the Time Traveler reaches forward to the twilight of the earth to witness a non-rotating planet locked in an eternal sunset, watching the remnants of what was the human race return at last to the sea in the form of football-shaped creatures.<br />While this movie is a feast to the imagination with its captivating sequences of time flashing by in an instant, if you are seeking more depth in a film version of a Wells novel, I'm sorry to say that this movie is not for you.

B00005N915|4.0|This is one of those few movies which you can watch more than once and it is probably advisable to do so.When seen again it becomes evident how well the various elements have been brought together to accentuate the story.The soundtrack,the use of surreal images and the acting indicate the depth of talent involved in this production.<br />The choice of songs truly captures the era,but for me it is the background music used during Harry's flashbacks and his symbolic dreams that make the movie as far as the soundtrack is concerned.It creates the impression that there is a malevolent presence over Harry and that the case has initiated images of a past come back to haunt him.<br />The flashbacks and surreal images make it a beautiful movie to watch and these images play on your mind as if they a making a psychological impact on yourself.These images are well timed and do not fragment the film nor does it come across as pretentious art.<br />The actor's performances are very strong in this film and there is not one actor I feel I could criticise.Robert de Niro's cameo appearance is brilliant and he portrayed his character as being a man of mysterious origin and is utterly confident in himself.This portrayel of the Devil is preferable to Al Pacino's more animated and comedic Lucifer.Pacino's character seems to be engineered for mass appeal in a blockbuster movie while De Niro's is created for suspense and chill factors.Mickey Rourke is superb and it is a pity that we do not see him in more movies.<br />Anybody wishing to view this movie should watch it again to analysis the story and only then can this production be truly appreciated.I gave this movie 8/10.

B000063K2W|5.0|This is one of the best films that I have ever seen about the emergence of modern women in 20th century America. It would work nicely as a companion piece to The Graduate. I, in fact, use both films when teaching a class on the role of women in 20th century America. The ending to the film, The Women, never ceases to amaze the young girls in the class...the idea of Mary throwing open her arms and welcoming back her wayward husband is shocking to most of the young students. It is certainly a period piece and certainly well worth viewing to see how few options were open to most women of the era. Putting everything into an historical perspective, it is difficult to believe that this was filmed less than two decades after American women were given the vote and only two decades prior to the Women's Rights movement actually kicking into high gear. It really is a wonderful depiction of women who where stuck in the middle of a changing society and how they were having to adapt and change in order to move onward.<br />As was noted in one of the earlier reviews, this film was made with an entirely female cast. I wouldn't swear to it, but I believe that I read somewhere that Cuckor was so obsessive about that fact that he even insisted that any of the animals who appear in the film also be female. That may have been Hollywood publicity, but it does make for fun viewing and an interesting anecdote.

B00003CXXR|5.0|Unlike the Lost Word JP this sequel remains closer to the viewpoints of the original, Jurassic Park. Reflecting the same concept of how dangerous biotechnology can be when developed with greedy motivations and no real moral reasoning. This opinion is held by the film's lead character, Dr. Alan Grant, who is from the first movie, as well as Ellie Sattler. I was glad to see that they brought back these two favorites of mine, and found them to remain true to their original characters in Jurassic Park. Although it seems like Grant was slightly made into the Indiana Jones type, because there are segments that give similar impressions. Also, JP III has some situations that are reminiscent to the first film, which was nice.<br />Despite what anyone else thinks, I'm going to say that the acting in this film is great, I really love it, and Tea Leoni did an admirable job. The actions and reactions of all the characters appear completely natural, making it a believable experience to watch. Once again the dinosaur animation is outstanding! The raptors are truly amazing! The movie becomes quite unpredictable, with suspense that just won't quit. All seasoned with a bit of humor at the right timing. The scenes are excellent and the camera flow is superb, making use of some fantastic angles to tell the story. It just has a way of grabbing your attention through sight, sound and emotion. <br />I'm a DIE-HARD Jurassic Park fan, and even if I wasn't, I still think I would recommend this movie. Because it's just one bazaar thrill ride of narrow escapes for those of you who like disaster/survival adventures where man verses nature, (or in this case, beasts of terror.) It has no out right swearing, but still heed the PG-13 rating. Compared to the 2 previous films,  this one has some of the most gruesome images. It's a bit obvious that a sequel is to follow, and it seems too, that this film was made with the prospect of another theme park ride in mind. But these things didn't totally ruinthe excitement of the movie. Personally, I think Jurassic Park III is a far BETTER sequel than the Lost World JP and wish I could double underline the word BETTER.<br />And oh yeah, even if you're somewhat of a Jurassic Park fan, don't hesitate a bit. Get this one on DVD or VHS; it won't be as disappointing as you might be lead to believe.

Anyway, be sure to pick this up. Avril has promising potential of being a classic female rock artist!
B000006OHL|5.0|One thing I'll never understand are the people who either don't get this film or the music that Bernard Herrmann composed for it. Get this straight right now: Taxi Driver is one of the greatest, best, and most important films ever made in any country at any time and Bernard Herrmann is without a doubt one of the top three or four film composers of all time and probably the greatest. The music Herrmann wrote for Taxi Driver, as were all his film scores, is wholly unique and perfectly tailored for the film it was written for. Unlike most other film scorers, Herrmann did not apply the exact same orchestral score to his films, but rather chose specific instruments that captured something essential about the film or scene. In his score for Taxi Driver, Herrmann uses the saxophone as the central voice. Since the beginnings of Jazz and blues, sax has been an instrument that speaks of human lonliness. Nothing, and I mean NOTHING, captures the mood, the feel, the very idea of lonliness better than a solitary saxaphone in the darkness and this score makes great use of this fact. Herrmann's Taxi Driver score veers deceptively from cheezy jazz, to deep blues, to ominous experimentalism. Second to the sax in Herrmann's score are the drums, which periodically either roll out an off-kilter military beat or disrupts the aural surroundings with the thud of a bass drum. Then, always, after the insanity, the generic jazziness comes back in, covering up the disturbing truth with a fairly innocuous veneer that by the end cannot contain the ugliness underneath. Bernard Herrmann was THINKING when he scored his films, and that, my friends, is what truly sets him apart from all other composers. His scores by themselves make better movies, in your head, anyway, that even some of the greatest filmmakers could perform with casts of thousands. Even the great Morricone is Herrmann's inferior, though to say such a thing is the height of absurdity. Bernard Herrmann didn't just write movie music, he made a statement and his contributions to the films he worked on rivalled those of the major crew memebers, from actors and director and scriptwriter to the cinematographer. And when Herrmann wrote for lesser films he sometimes provided the one and only thing that made these films watchable (just listen to his score for Journey to the Center of the Earth and you'll know, but if you still can't see/hear it then I hereby revoke your right to watch movies and command you to seek counseling immediately!). Okay, so there you have it, the undisputable truth. Yes, Taxi Driver is, especially in these days of hyperactive overstatement, a boring film to some degree and the music for it does deceive the simple minded among us with its difficult to penetrate veneer. But if you are still stuck in the cranky infant stage of \\"Waaah! I'm bored, someone stimulate me!\\" then heaven help you. You need to grow up, and right quick. You need to give things time, you need to seek insight, you need to grow up and get a brain. Don't be swayed by your knee jerk \\"opinions,\\" learn to understand things, learn to see and hear, or get off my planet right now.
B000066NW0|4.0|Losing Grip- One of the better tracks on the album. Has a catchy hard rock chorus and tight guitar riffs. 4/5 stars.<br />Complicated- I'm soo sick of this tune that I'm not even going to bother...2/5 stars.<br />Sk8er Boi- My LEAST favorite track on the album. One of the highlights again. 4/5 stars.<br />Anything But Ordinary- Great lyrics, a very unique rock track! 4/5 stars.<br />Thing I'll Never Say- Another impressive rock track. 6305265666|5.0|The two young leads in this beautiful rendering of the Cinderella Story posess such lovely chemistry, one can actually forgive some of the historical mistakes included in this film. Dougray Scott portrays the handsome, regal (if somewhat befuddled)Prince Henry who 'suffers from an arranged marriage' and wishes 'only to be freed from his gilded cage'(ie; the responsibilities of his royal lineage) and find his true love and purpose in life. He finds both in the form of a poor servant girl Danielle (Drew Barrymore actually stretching a bit, albeit with an iffy accent that comes and goes)whom he mistakes as a Countess and falls madly in love with. Angelica Houston is note perfect as the evil Stepmother Rodmilla DeGhent, she makes every line she utters fairly drip with contempt and bitterness, and Patrick Godfrey is flawless as Leonardo Da Vinci, the artist in residence at the castle, home to King Francis(Timothy West) and his lovely Queen (Judy Parfitt). This is essentially a typical boy meets girl story and the resolution is reached almost too easily and tidy for my taste, but what elevates this piece far and above it's peers is the lush cinematography and enthusiastic cast who seem to be having the time of thier lives. \\"Ever After\\" is grandly entertaining.

B00005R2M3|3.0|After resisting her new, blonde-bombshell American debut album for so long, I finally gave in and bought Laundry Service. B00005QZWI|5.0|While Peter Jackson's film was one of the best ever made in any genre, and the acting was marvelous - if Tolkien was the movie's heart,  Shore's score was the soul of The Fellowship of the Ring.  When I first heard that Howard Shore was scoring LOTR, I was quite unfamiliar with his work.  I had no idea what to expect but was more than pleasantly surprised after seeing the movie.  The soundtrack to the Fellowship of the Ring is almost Wagnerian in scope, full orchestra, heavy brass and percussion, and chorus. He put the choruses to much greater use than Jerry Goldsmith did in \\"The Omen,\\" John Williams in \\"The Phantom Menace,\\" backing not only action sequences, but love, friendship, and goodbye sequences in the film.  Depending on the mood of a scene, he uses his music to paint the emotions of the characters before they have spoken a single word, as heard in \\"Concerning Hobbits\\" - to accentuate the action sequences, as heard in \\"The Bridge of Khazad Dum\\" -  and to make the characters in this wonderful fantasy seem almost tragic, heroic, and completely three-dimensional, as heard in \\"Amon Hen.\\" <br />Almost every composer has her/his own unique style. (There are a few hacks out there blatantly ripping of the classics - note for note.)  This soundtrack is not one endless string of melodies. Shore's scoring makes abundant use of solo flutes, violins, recorders, solo treble voices to create music that is both familiar but completely original.  At times Shore's LOTR score has a Celtic flavor, but not enough to make you feel you are at a Riverdance concert.  While William's music is highly thematic and very structured - verses, choruses, repeats, etc., Shore's music seems to be thematic but with less structure, and very intense.  Percussive in the action sequences.  In the theater my hands were over my eyes during the Khazad Dum sequence.  I now realize one of the contributing factors,  other than my fear of heights, was the score. On the other end of the scale, Enya's Elven touch on her solo vocals in mesmerizing.  If you are buying this CD for the toe-tapping melodies you'll be sadly disappointed, but the job of the composer is to write music which blends with the action of the film - not produce a hit record.<br />There have been some wonderful soundtracks out there in recent history.  The Shawshank Redemption.  Glory.  The Red Violin.  Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.  Phantom Menace.  Just to name a few.  And The Fellowship of the Ring can take its place with them as one of the great scores of all time.

B000002U82|5.0|A themed album about the potential of society's pressures to drive a fellow to paranoid insanity, \\"Dark Side of the Moon\\" was a quantum leap for Pink Floyd, launching them out of BBC Top Gear reverie and into arenas and stadiums. At this time, Roger Waters' lyrics weren't yet so weighty or preachy as to mention their subjects by name (as they would become on \\"Animals\\" and forever later), so his brilliant words fit extremely well with the beautifully constructed, psychedelic music, mostly the creations of Pink Floyd's music department (Dave Gilmour, Richard Wright, and to a slightly lesser extent, Nick Mason).<br />The lyrics never overshadow or outweigh the music, which even by itself could have made a substantial landmark of a record. Two of Wright's musical responsibilities, 'The Great Gig and the Sky' and 'Us and Them' are evocative masterpieces, and Waters' lyrics on the latter are nothing short of eerily poignant. In fact, these were probably the best lyrics ever given to a psychedelic-oriented rock album, even if by 1973, Pink Floyd's \\"psychedelic\\" reputation was ready to fall away to more deliberate pieces of work; 'Money' was the biggest single of Floyd's career at the time ('Another Brick in the Wall Part 2' was still six years away), and 'Time' is an album-rock radio staple to this day.<br />The use of sound effects and spoken word snippets throughout the record were effective and hugely influential for many acts and albums to follow, but it's the flawlessly constructed, equal-band effort that makes it such a wonderful piece of work. Its mystique allowed for \\"Dark Side of the Moon\\"'s appearances on Billboard's album chart for a record-breaking fourteen years. Arguably \\"the 'Sgt. Pepper' of the 70s,\\" this monumental 9-track disc made Pink Floyd a name as commonly spouted as that of the Beatles, though Floyd kept their music somehow greater than the individuals who made it.
B000002JNJ|5.0|The fifth album by the clearly poised to rise to the top Pantera, was probably one of the last truly \\"metal\\" albums in the mainstream in the 90's (unless you consider nu metal metal) . There is a clear quality and almost innocent aura about the album since Phil and company have steadily become more extreme  in lifestyle and music as time went on. Far Beyond Driven is half noisy metal and half groove splendor, Vulgar Display is excellent and much better, but Cowboys from Hell is classic. Sounding like a clear combination between their 1988 album \\"Power Metal\\" (Phil's debut),  and the late eighties early nineties band Exhorder, with a bit of Testament and Metallica thrown in for good measure, Cowboys from Hell still has a charm that has not dilluted throughout the years. It also has power, melody and variation, something than most bands influenced by them could learn more. Also recommended is the aforementioned  \\"Power Metal\\" which has a lot more Halford esque screams and almost more intensity. The only thing is good luck finding it, you can only find it by the way of often expensive bootleg. I have heard most of the mp3s and can honestly say it is definitely NOT GLAM though the cover is a bit cheesy and close to it. Its too bad theyre ashamed of their image back then and don't differentiate it from the music when even \\"I am the Night\\" had some cool stuff too (also not as \\"glam\\" as people say).  Maybe we should petition the Pantera camp to rerelease these! (Though we know it will probably never happen!)
B0000025D0|5.0|Bruce Springsteen endured nearly three years of court battles and personal betrayal after his 1975 breakthrough &quot;Born To Run.&quot; This two and a half year stall in his newfound streak of acclaim added to the many frustrations in his creative career. All of that angst and bitterness that came from three years of this inspired the genuine pain and scorn of Springsteen's 1978 masterpiece &quot;Darkness on the Edge of Town.&quot;<br />In the course of these endless legal battles, Springsteen saw a true darkness in people, even in his personal managers and companions. This realization no doubt inspired the Boss to turn his generic subject matter of exploring the lives of ordinary people, into a more brooding look at the reality that comes with everyday life, and in everyday lives. &quot;Darkness on the Edge of Town&quot; is in many ways a rock and roll echo of the writings of short story author Sherwood Anderson--expressing the often frustrated lives of ordinary people in small cities (the one place many people only expect to find a naive eutopia, while most of us expect the darker reality to be found in the dirty streets of the big city). Springsteen's 1978 masterpiece of scorn and pain is a close contender for the title of his best work, mainly for two reasons; at this time, his habit of expressing the frustrations of ordinary people had not yet lost its luster and fresh originality. But most of all, &quot;Darkness on the Edge of Town&quot; strays far from what flaws most albums expressing this subject--cliche`. Here, Springsteen's agonizing, poignant lyrics match the raw instrumentation, which is more separated to punctuate the album's ruggedly emotional mood. While this is only one of the things that makes &quot;Darkness on the Edge of Town&quot; a fresh break from all of the other attempts by other performers to express the frustrations of everyday people, most of all, it is genuine and inspired, it is real, full of purpose and reality. Springsteen's work here is a rock and roll expression of the sighs that come from small-town gossipers. The character studies in &quot;Darkness on the Edge of Town&quot; are perfectly balanced, from the ghosts that haunt the wicked woman of 'Candy's Room' to the bitter, self-pitying man in 'Adam Raised a Cain.' The title track alone is the ultimate anthem of the album, and of the people described within it. The power of &quot;Darkness on the Edge of Town&quot; is an even balance of subtlety and raw power.<br />It would be quite easy for me to sum up how I feel about this album by raving that Springsteen's &quot;Darkness on the Edge of Town&quot; is the greatest rock and roll album of all time, but it is quite true. No album before or after it has expressed such a raw and genuine purpose, something rock and roll music has always stood for since its birth in the mid-50s. It is honest and dead-on, haunting and real. But most of all, true to its purpose, &quot;Darkness on the Edge of Town&quot; is the anthem for the bitter, the frustrated, the determined.is a rock and roll expression of the sighs that come from small-town gossipers. The character studies in &quot;Darkness on the Edge of Town&quot; are perfectly balanced, from the ghosts that haunt the wicked woman of 'Candy's Room' to the bitter, self-pitying man in 'Adam Raised a Cain.' The title track alone is the ultimate anthem of the album, and of the people described within it. The power of &quot;Darkness on the Edge of Town&quot; is an even balance of subtlety and raw power.<BR>It would be quite easy for me to sum up how I feel about this album by raving that Springsteen's &quot;Darkness on the Edge of Town&quot; is the greatest rock and roll album of all time, but it is quite true. No album before or after it has expressed such a raw and genuine purpose, something rock and roll music has always stood for since its birth in the mid-50s. It is honest and dead-on, haunting and real. But most of all, true to its purpose, &quot;Darkness on the Edge of Town&quot; is the anthem for the bitter, the frustrated, the determined.

All the familiar horror staples are here, and the characters that live the longest are the ones who realize they're living out a horror movie and play by the rules.  Largely camp, \\"Scream\\" does boast some genuinely scary segments well-orchestrated by legendary horror master Wes Craven, particularly the Drew Barrymore scene that opens the film.  But mostly it's just silly, with all the weaknesses that always doom slasher pix:  too many vapid, sex-starved teens, a reliance on cheap gore instead of real chills, and a lot of low-brow \\"humor.\\"  Moreover, \\"Scream's\\" killer is a terribly inefficient killing machine.  Ghostface often bungles his murders by running or falling over every obstacle in sight, and even when he catches a victim can't figure out how to finish them off.  Neve Campbell's character is likeable, resourceful,  and attractive, but given her inferior competition it's not hard for her to stand out.<br />\\"Scream\\" is a big disappointment, and no matter how many teens swear otherwise it's nothing a horror movie should be.  For a more mature thriller, check out \\"The Sixth Sense\\" and leave the screams for the kids.
